statement.tex: \text{A card from a pack of 52 playing cards}\\ \text{is lost. From the remaining cards of the}\\ \text{pack, three cards are drawn at random}\\ \text{(without replacement) and are found to be}\\ \text{all spades. Find the probability of the}\\ \text{lost card being a spade.}

step.context: \textbf{What probability do we need to find?}\\ \text{Use the event definitions given below.}\\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Event} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline L & \text{The card lost is a spade.} \\ S_3 & \text{Three spades are drawn.} \\ \hline \end{tabular}
step.reason: \text{We don't know that the lost card is a spade.}\\ \text{That is why we are finding the probability.}\\ \textbf{But }\text{we do know that three spades have}\\ \text{been drawn. Hence, we need to start thinking }\\ \text{about conditional probability - the condition }\\ \text{being that }S_3\text{ has occurred. Or, }P(L\vert S_3).

step.context: \text{The table below shows some probabilities.}\\ \text{The probabilities are correct. But we don't}\\ \text{know what columns A and B are.}\\ \textbf{What are columns A and B?}
step.tex: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline & A & B \\ \hline \text{First card = Spade} & \frac{12}{51} & \frac{13}{51}\\ \hline \text{Second card = Spade}& \frac{11}{50} & \frac{12}{50} \\ \hline \text{Third card = Spade} & \frac{10}{49} & \frac{11}{49} \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline A & \text{The card lost is a spade} = L \\ \hline B & \text{The card lost is not a spade} = \bar{L} \\ \hline \end{tabular}

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline & A & B \\ \hline \text{First card = Spade} & \frac{12}{51} & \frac{13}{51}\\ \hline \text{Second card = Spade}& \frac{11}{50} & \frac{12}{50} \\ \hline \text{Third card = Spade} & \frac{10}{49} & \frac{11}{49} \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline A & \text{The card lost is not a spade} = \bar{L}\\ \hline B & \text{The card lost is a spade} = L \\ \hline \end{tabular}
step.reason: \text{Once a card is lost, we would either have}\\ \text{12 spades remaining or 13 spades. It is then}\\ \text{that we start drawing three cards. And the}\\ \text{probability of getting three successive spades}\\ \text{will depend on what card was lost initially.}

step.context: \text{Your friend makes the following claims.}\\ \textbf{Is he correct?}
step.reason: \text{The event }S_3\text{ we defined in Step 2 is really}\\ S_3 = (C_1=spade)\cap(C_2=spade)\cap(C_3=spade).\\ \text{Hence, we must multiply the probabilities.}\\ \textbf{But }\text{the probabilities we listed in Step 2}\\ \text{were also for when a card was lost initially.}\\ \text{Hence, it is not }P(S_3)\text{ that we know, but }\\ \mathbf{P(S_3\vert L)}\text{ and }\mathbf{P(S_3\vert\bar{L}).}

step.context: \textbf{Putting it all together.}\\ \text{Is the work done below correct?}
step.reason: \text{In the formula below,}\\ \begin{align} P(L\vert S_3) &= \underbrace{\dfrac{P(S_3\vert L)\cdot P(L)} {P(S_3\vert L)\cdot P(L) + P(S_3\vert \bar{L})\cdot P(\bar{L})}}_{\text{Bayes' Theorem}} \end{align} \\ \text{we know }P(S_3\vert L)\text{ and }P(S_3\vert\bar{L}).\\ \text{But we do not know what }P(L)\text{ and }P(\bar{L})\text{ are.}\\ \text{So, remind yourself what event L is.}\\ \text{It is the event that the lost card is a spade.}\\ \text{So, if a card is lost from a full deck, then the}\\ \text{probability that it is a spade is} \\ \quad P(L) = \dfrac{13}{52} = \dfrac{1}{4}\implies P(\bar{L}) = \dfrac{3}{4}.
